clinical_study.brief_title: Using Mother's Raw Milk Could Improve Breastfeeding in Hospitalized Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: Using Mother's Raw Milk Could Improve Breastfeeding in Hospitalized Neonates

brief_summary.textblock: Despite the importance of breast milk for sick or preterm neonates, there is currently no consensus regarding the use of raw mother's own milk (MOM) in neonatal units. The aims of this study are to: (a) describe factors associated with the use of raw MOM; (b) investigate the association between early use of raw MOM and breastfeeding continuation at discharge and up to 6 months later.

primary_outcome.description: Maternal breastfeeding is defined as the consumption of any MOM. It is classed as "exclusive" when all the fed milk will be MOM or "partial" when it will be completed by other milk or food.

arm_group.arm_group_label: exposed group : early raw mother's own milk
arm_group.description: The use of raw MOM is considered as "early" when it begins before day 7.

arm_group.arm_group_label: unexposed group : no use of raw mother's own milk
arm_group.description: Neonates who receive, or not, raw MOM before day 7.

intervention.description: Infants receive mother's own milk before day 7.
intervention.arm_group_label: exposed group : early raw mother's own milk

study_pop.textblock: Neonates from two French participating centres.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Admitted neonates between April 2012 and June 2013 are eligible if they are intended to be breastfeed and hospitalized ≥7 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Neonates with parents not fluent in French.
